body: More and more organisations and individuals are seeing the value of data, from saving time and money in an organisation, to making data informed decisions or improving products and services for users. In order to make data more understandable, we need to be able to present findings and insight from data. In this module we look at how data has changed the way we tell stories.
title: Introduction to data storytelling

_skills.outcome: Explain how data has changed the way we find stories
Explain how data has changed the way we tell stories
Give examples of data stories

body: To tell a powerful story you need to be able undertake the majority - if not all - of the stages of data storytelling. Success will depend on understanding the time requirement of each stage in the process.
title: The four step process

_skills.outcome: Explain the data storytelling process
Plan a data storytelling project

body: When working with data, it's critical to understand your rights and your responsibility in ensuring legal and ethical use of data. This module introduces the aspects of law that cover the use of content in different scenarios.
displayTitle: Understanding your rights to use data
title: Understanding your rights to use data

_skills.outcome: Describe how copyright and licensing relate to open data
Identify instances of open licenses and effective application
Explain how copyright exceptions affect the use of data

body: Data plays a key role in storytelling, but not all data is easy to find. This module looks at where you can start to find data and how to find data that's hidden on the web.
title: Gathering data

_skills.outcome: Explain the difference between downloadable and hidden data
Find downloadable data
Find hidden data
Describe the benefit of using hidden data

body: Organising data ready for it to be processed is an essential skills for anyone working with data. In this module we explore how to design and implement a structure for a dataset that can be easily understood by others.
title: Organising data

_skills.outcome: Identify good and bad spreadsheet layouts
Create good column titles for a spreadsheet
Use header rows and freeze functions in spreadsheets
Use different data types in a spreadsheet

body: Data containing errors leads to stories containing errors. Before any analysis can take place, you need to be able to identify and remove them from data. This module looks at common errors and useful tools to remove them.
title: Cleaning data

_skills.outcome: Explain how and why data needs to be cleaned
Recognise a number of errors in data
Clean a dataset

body: Once data is clean, it's ready for analysis; but this analysis doesn't have to use complex statistical methods. Common analysis techniques such as filtering and pivot tables can be equally as effective.
title: Filtering and pivot tables

_skills.outcome: Apply filters to a spreadsheet
Sort data in a spreadsheet
Apply formula to a spreadsheet
Create a set of analytics for a spreadsheet

body: There are many different types of visualisation, from common graphs to advanced statistical plots to geographic representations. Learn more about the options for bringing your data to life in this module.
title: Data visualisation formats

_skills.outcome: Describe a number data visualisations and their usage
Choose an appropriate visualisation for data

body: Picking the right visualisation is only the first part of telling effective stories. Plotting the right data in the correct way, making good use of colour and other visual cues is essential to making the story “pop out” at the audience.
title: Data visualisation best practice

_skills.outcome: Describe how the human brain interprets visually presented data
Use colour and pop-out to help clearly present information

body: The use of visual deception can create intrigue, but it can also be used to mislead. You should be able to choose deception techniques that engage and inform, and avoid those which intentionally mislead.
title: Visual deception

_skills.outcome: Identify a number of deception techniques in visulisations

body: More and more organisations and individuals are seeing the value of data, from saving time and money in an organisation, to making data informed decisions or improving products and services for users. In order to make data more understandable, we need to be able to present findings and insight from data. This means creating a memorable story which not only requires an effective visualisation but an engaging narrative.
title: Narrating your story

_skills.outcome: List the steps writing a narrative
Write effective headlines
Identify techniques to help share your story
